message: Hmm. Either that or you have smarter spammers.
Googling for this was so not working :/
i stand corrected
That's a really good idea BTW
It's not the kind of solution that will work for all sites (not by a long shot), and it also won't really do much if you're a high profile site that spammers actively target.
we use tweepy
It looks like it's in the API though, under "created_at": http://dev.twitter.com/doc/get/users/show
@carljm I tried something like that but with no success. I reckon my text field name wasn't tempting enough.
I want to measure how long they've had the (Twitter) account registered, to avoid newly-created spam accounts from gaining access to features
oh yeah twitter not facebook. I don't think you can get that. you can get their number of followers though.
@KuraFire That's a neat idea.
I also would like to know if it is at all possible to retrieve a time stamp of the user's registration date in any way, after they've Auth'd.
i don't think you can get their registration date. what exactly would you want, the time they first created their facebook account?
Not quite as helpful
hmm interesting. so we make primarily facebook games and there are a lot of fake facebook accounts just for game-playing

it's not clear that we should block them, though - some people just have a totally separate set of "game-playing friends" and don't want to broadcast to their normal friends that they play these games
I'm integrating with Twitter for commenting on my site. If your account is too new, I don't trust you to be legit.
I have those on occasion. ;)
And as such, you won't be able to comment on blog posts.

@KuraFire re the "I'm human" checkbox on your contact form, you can achieve an equivalent level of protection without bothering humans at all, with a honeypot field. Add a text field, give it a tempting name like "body", give it display: none in CSS, drop anything that comes in with content in that field.
Like the "I'm human" checkbox it won't stand up if you're high-profile or they're determined, but it's worked pretty well for me on a number of smaller sites.
Is there a resource anywhere with a list of fields that have proven effective?
And I use this app to make it easy: https://github.com/sunlightlabs/django-honeypot
Wait, that's their registration date? I thought that was for the profile image!
Huh.
<- feels foolish now, heh.
why do you want to avoid newly-created accounts, anyway?
I can see it being a reward to long-standing Twitter users, depending on what type of features are offered.
but i can see it being handy in some cases
Commenting will probably be closed automatically after 4 weeks, and I want accounts to be at least 4 weeks old.
That excludes real people from commenting on my articles if they have thus far refrained from signing up for Twitter, but given my target audience, that's not a likely scenario.

Those who legitimately didn't discover/get onto Twitter yet and want to comment can simply use the Contact form to email me. It has a nice, simple, "I'm human, don't spam-filter me bro"-style checkbox which thus far, spam bots haven't figured out yet.

But, I think it'll work quite well. People don't usually make spam twitter accounts to keep them around doing nothing for four weeks, and it's rare that spam accounts survive on Twitter for that long if they spam.
Any peace of mind is good peace of mind. :)
I probably don't.
I could try that when I retool my form for the v2 site
@KuraFire Not that I've seen. I've used "content" and "message" both successfully.
Thanks :)
But, the original question has only been answered once: Tweepy. Is that the best solution, by consensus?
I use tweepy for everything I do with twitter, don't have any complaints
Right on, thanks.
I wrote my own thing, unfortunately that's not great advice.
@ericflo why'd you write your own?
Because I have NIH
No, honestly, because we're really using very little of the Twitter API, it's really *very* little code, and it's nice to have it follow the rest of our style and implementation preferences.
I think he's just showing off ;)
https://gist.github.com/846469ae4dd42b63d836
^^ That's our implementation
Just updated it to show how to get friends https://gist.github.com/846469ae4dd42b63d836#file_how_to_get_friends.py
Oh, note the code in the facebook part that valiantly tries to get a username based off of their profile url :(
Why the is_male ?
No good reason
@KuraFire I assume you're thinking of this? http://www.sarahmei.com/blog/2010/11/26/disalienation/
Not even (though I do like that post), was just wondering why you even stored it at all, and why in that way.
Yeah, I dunno, I think I just thought it'd be nice to be able to do quick demographic queries
the more data the better I say ;)
Probably doesn’t help that people oAuthing with Twitter don’t get to populate that field at all ;)
Yeah, it's kind of a worthless field, actually most of those are, it's just "grab it if you can" type stuff
@ericflo I would not call that "very little code"
Well, I kind of included a bunch of ancillary stuff, the actual code that fetches data from Twitter is nothing
